title: What are the differences between 'moral', 'value', and 'moral value'? - Quora

response.answer_text: MORAL is defined as: an adjective, The definition of moral is something that relates to the rules of right and http://wrong.An example of moral is governing principles of a religious group. As a noun, Moral is defined as a principle that governs right and wrong or the lesson of a fable. An example of moral is the commandment "Thou shalt not kill."An example of moral is "Slow and steady wins the race" from "The Tortoise and the Hare." VALUE is defined as: noun, plural noun: values, 1.the regard that something is held to deserve; the importance, worth, or usefulness of something."your support is of great value. EXAMPLE: Similar:meritworthusefulnessuseutilitypracticalityadvantagedesirabilitybenefitgainprofitgoodservicehelphelpfulnessassistanceeffectivenessefficacyavailimportancesignificancepointsensemileage 2. a person's principles or standards of behavior; one's judgment of what is important in life. EXAMPLE: "they internalize their parents' rules and values" MORAL VALUES mens the set of moral statements that someone highly valuess, such that they habitually do them!

Each one is a different aspect of “good” or “goodness”, closely related. Morality refers to what is intrinsically good. Values are the goals (the good) of a group or individual, what they consider good. Moral values are what they consider intrinsically good.
